channel.title: Articles | Mail Online
channel.description: MailOnline - get the latest breaking news, showbiz & celebrity photos, sport news & rumours, viral videos and top stories from MailOnline, Daily Mail and Mail on Sunday newspapers.

item.title: Boris Johnson and Emmanuel Macron's WhatsApp messages on quarantine-free travel blindsided officials
item.description: The Mail on Sunday has learnt the Prime Minister and French President regularly converse over the messaging service, away from the prying eyes of aides.

item.title: DR JOHN LEE says 'R' rate is less reliable than a weather forecast
item.description: In the words of former Supreme Court Judge Lord Sumption, lockdown is without doubt the greatest interference with personal liberty in our history.

item.title: Landmark study: Virus didn't come from animals in Wuhan market
item.description: Specialist biologists suggest the virus was taken into Wuhan's seafood market by a human. The news comes as Beijing thwarts global efforts to establish the source of the virus.

item.title: Female comedians are taking politics to TikTok amid the coronavirus pandemic
item.description: Female comedians are taking politics to TikTok amid the coronavirus pandemic - including a drunk Donald Trump and storytime with Boris Johnson.

item.title: Public support for government's handling of coronavirus slides 9% in a week
item.description: The survey by Opinium found 39% backed the Government's response, down from 48% a week ago. Those saying they disapproved have risen from 36% last week to 42%.

item.title: Bake Off's Nadiya Hussain reveals her battle with coronavirus pandemic panic attacks
item.description: Bake-off star Nadiya Hussain reveals how her lifelong battle with anxiety has been rekindled - by fears for her mother and sisters who are working on the front line in the battle against coronavirus.

item.title: Care home chiefs say Matt Hancock's total lack of face-to-face meetings 'led to lethal mistakes'
item.description: Embattled Matt Hancock failed to hold a single face-to-face meeting with care home bosses in the weeks leading up to the lockdown.

item.title: Doctors are at war on schools
item.description: Dr Chaand Nagpaul, the chairman of the British Medical Association, had told the National Education Union that it was 'absolutely right' to object to the move back to lessons.

item.title: Prince Andrew and ANOTHER sex slave
item.description: Prince Andrew was at the New York mansion of paedophile billionaire Jeffrey Epstein at the same time as a young woman understood to have been abused for years as a sex slave.

item.title: Pupils won't be allowed to take a pencil case to school when they return
item.description: Speaking at Saturday's Downing Street briefing, Dr Jenny Harries said that pencil cases were 'easier to control' than lunchboxes.

item.title: Adele gives 'Prince Harry and Meghan advice on settling into Beverly Hills life'
item.description: Adele, 32, has allegedly become friends with Prince Harry and Meghan Markle after they moved nearby in Beverly Hills and is giving them tips on how to settle in.

item.title: Sir James Dyson is named top of the Sunday Times Rich List for the first time
item.description: More than half of the country's billionaires have seen losses as high as £6bn, with the combined wealth of the 1,000 wealthiest individuals and families plunging for the first time since 2009.

item.title: Baby dies of coronavirus-linked Kawasaki disease aged eight months
item.description: Alexander Parsons, who had no underlying health conditions, passed away aged eight months after being admitted to Plymouth's Derriford Hospital on April 6 and diagnosed with the illness.

item.title: More competitors reveal they were ill at the World Military Games
item.description: Jacqueline Bock, part of the German volleyball team, told The Mail on Sunday how she and her colleagues contracted Covid-19 at the event in the city.

item.title: At last! Harry and Meghan are paying us back for Frogmore...
item.description: The pale pink peonies - flowers that Meghan has said make her 'endlessly happy' - are coming into bloom around Frogmore Cottage. Their sweet fragrance drifts across the lawns and grounds.

item.title: Homes market surges as buyers burst out of lockdown gloom and head out of town to view properties
item.description: Savills estate agents say interest in new homes has increased by 30 per cent. The housing market has burst since lockdown restrictions were lifted midweek, with 906 homes sold on Wednesday.

item.title: Modern Family actor Fred Willard dead at 86 from natural causes
item.description: Comic talent Fred Willard has passed away at 86. The Best In Show actor died from natural causes, rep Glenn Schwartz confirmed.

item.title: Fury in Germany with thousands protest across country over lockdown measures
item.description: Thousands of protesters gathered again in Stuttgart (pictured) Munich and Berlin on Saturday, with police out in force after some protests turned violent.

item.title: How getting fit can help defeat Covid-19
item.description: Cardiologist Professor Kausik Ray, at Imperial College London, said: 'Infections place huge stresses on the body, particularly the heart and lungs.'

item.title: Care home forced to close after 15 residents died of coronavirus
item.description: Temple Court in Kettering, Northants, was believed to be Covid-free before the NHS admissions but it has been forced to shut after staff fell ill.

item.title: ALEXANDRA SHULMAN: The sun is out and I've lost 2lb, so why do I feel so gloomy?
item.description: The day that tennis courts, golf courses and garden centres were joyously reopened, I hit a personal low.

item.title: Boris Johnson hails British 'fortitude' as he aims to draw a line under confusion over new rules
item.description: British people's 'fortitude' will enable then to survive the Covid-19 crisis and regain 'the freedoms they hold dear', Boris Johnson declares today.

item.title: Police arrest activists as anti-lockdown protesters gather in Hyde Park
item.description: Masses people have gathered in Hyde Park, including the brother of Jeremy Corbyn, to protest against the coronavirus lockdown while brandishing signs reading 'I will not be masked.'

item.title: Border Force intercepts six boats carrying 90 migrants including three toddlers and a baby
item.description: A baby and three toddlers were among those in six migrant boats that made it into Dover, Kent this morning. One other boat made it into East Sussex. 17 migrants were taken back to Calais in France.

item.title: DR MICHAEL MOSLEY: Why coronavirus is still a mystery
item.description: DR MICHAEL MOSLEY: Despite intense research, there are still fundamental things we don't understand about Covid-19., which is leading to contradictory and changing advice.

item.title: A rear gunner on a Lancaster, Ron Needle, 19, had the loneliest and deadliest job of the war
item.description: JOHN NICHOL: The leaden skies spread from horizon to horizon. Ground crews have been working the snow ploughs all day to keep the runways clear. Now at last, the moment has come.

item.title: Britain's chief Brexit negotiator warns of No Deal if vital talks fail in 15 days' time
item.description: David Frost, who heads the Prime Minister's 'Taskforce Europe', told Ministers to 'take the moral high ground' negotiating with EU counterparts in the face of stubbornness from Brussels

item.title: Heathrow trials thermal imaging temperature checks for passengers arriving in Britain
item.description: In a trial set to start as soon as Thursday, passengers arriving at Heathrow Airport's (pictured) Terminal 2 will be screened for raised temperatures by thermal imaging cameras.

item.title: Day trippers ignore pleas from English countryside with 15 MILLION people to visit parks and beaches
item.description: Today marks the first weekend of eased lockdown restrictions as the British public are expected to rush outdoors to enjoy good weather in parks and beaches across England and Wales.

item.title: PETER HITCHENS: Furlough billions? Just a giant payday loan in YOUR name
item.description: PETER HITCHENS: Nobody has ever seen so much wild spending of non-existent money before in peacetime. Some idiots nowadays think you can do this without consequences.

item.title: Hell-raiser Liam Gallagher's £4million oasis of calm
item.description: Rowdy rocker Liam Gallagher has spent almost £4million on a mock Tudor mansion in one of London's quietest streets, The Mail on Sunday can reveal.

item.title: Chinese nationalists urge President Xi to seize Taiwan
item.description: IAN BIRRELL: The island nation of Taiwan is almost unique among locked down developed countries with just seven deaths and 440 confirmed cases.

item.title: Vital lessons investors can learn from coronavirus crisis
item.description: We asked experts for key investment lessons that can be learned. If we take them on board, we could come out of lockdown with better money-making skills.

item.title: Prince William talks mental health with Premier League stars
item.description: The programme: Football, Prince William And Our Mental Health, will be shown on May 28, according to the short clip on Twitter from the royal's mental health initiative Heads Together.

item.title: Greece, Italy and France, which records just 96 deaths, reopen beaches as coronavirus lockdown eases
item.description: Scores of people flocked to the beaches to make up for time spent indoors and to capitalise on the arrival of one of the first heatwaves of the year, with social distancing rules still remaining in place.

item.title: Donald Trump confirms he is considering restoring funding to the WHO
item.description: Donald Trump tweeted on Saturday morning saying no final decision has been made on restoring aid and that US funding for the global health agency remains frozen.

item.title: Gavin Williamson promises it WILL be safe for children to go back to school on June 1
item.description: The Education Secretary attempted to pile pressure on opponents of his plans tonight as he warned of the dire 'consequences if children did not start returning to school.

item.title: Thousands march chanting 'death to fascism' in protest at Catholic mass
item.description: Thousands of people marched in Sarajevo, Bosnia on Saturday against a Catholic mass being held to honour Croatia's Nazi collaborators and civilians killed after World War II.

item.title: Monty Don says fond farewell to his adorable four-legged TV co-star Nigel who captivated viewers
item.description: Right from the beginning, Nigel has been different. It helps that he's good-looking - beautiful even - but so are lots of dogs. Nigel, however, has that rare quality of drawing attention to himself.

item.title: 'Why are you not wearing masks?' Brave policemen arresting a boy with a KNIFE are shouted at
item.description: Three officers were forced to battle back against concerned passersby while patting down a man who was carrying a knife outside Walthamstow Central Station in London.

item.title: Here comes the gran!
item.description: EXCLUSIVE: In the 1960s she was on tour with the Beatles. But tonight Crissy Lee, 76, will have to get by without a little help from her friends as she tries to impress the Britain's Got Talent judges.

item.title: Serbia sends army to border with Croatia to 'secure' three migrants camps holding 1,500
item.description: Serbia's Defence Ministry said that President Vucic ordered the troop deployment to 'secure' three migrant camps near the western town of Sid that are housing some 1,500 people.

item.title: BT Sport app BUCKLES under the demand of sport-deprived armchair supporters tuning into Bundesliga
item.description: Live football was played for the first time since the coronavirus outbreak today as fixtures took place in empty stadiums, pictured, with many coaching staff wearing masks.

item.title: Moment suspended police officer uses Taser on 'bystander' as he is investigated for THIRD incident
item.description: Shocking footage captures a suspended police officer using a Taser on a 'bystander' on February 27 after a car crash in Handsworth, Birmingham, as he is investigated in a third incident.

item.title: Mourning families put yellow hearts in their windows in a tribute to their loved ones
item.description: Hannah Gompertz's grandfather David put a yellow heart in his window when his wife died of coronavirus at the beginning of May. Some 34,4666 people have died in Britain of the illness.

item.title: Police launch 'sexual assault' appeal after lorry driver kisses pensioner woman on the cheek
item.description: Derbyshire police have been ridiculed by social media users after launching an appeal to find a lorry driver - for kissing a pensioner on the cheek.

item.title: French police arrest Africa's most wanted man, 84, for 'arming militias in 1994 Rwandan genocide'
item.description: Rwandan businessman Felicien Kabuga, 84, is accused of equipping ethnic Hutu extremists in the 100-day genocide that killed more than 800,000 ethnic Tutsis and moderate Hutus in 1994.

item.title: Prue Leith, 80, says we should be saving the young over the old amid coronavirus
item.description: Prue Leith has admitted she believes it is more important to save the young over the old during the coronavirus pandemic.

item.title: Fury as British Transport Police chief makes 480-MILE trip from Glasgow to second home in Yorkshire
item.description: BTP confirmed Chief Superintendent Eddie Wylie returned to Yorkshire from his rented flat in Glasgow on two occasions between March 21 and May 13, but said he did not breach regulations.

item.title: Britain reveals hundreds more coronavirus deaths
item.description: Education Secretary Gavin Williamson revealed the figures, which include fatalities in all settings, at tonight's Downing Street press briefing.

item.title: Grieving daughter tells how she had to watch her parents' joint funeral over video link
item.description: Katie Orchard, 30, lost parents Richard, 87, and Pat Telford, 72, from Nottingham. The loving couple died in separate hospitals and had a joint funeral but family members could not attend.

item.title: Restrictions are eased in Italy after three months of lockdown with people free to fly from June 3
item.description: From June 3, Italy will reopen its border to European tourists. Regions have also been told told they can fully reopen their economies under strict safety measures.

item.title: Man is jailed for eight years after dousing childhood friend in acid
item.description: Ibrahim Khan, 22,(pictured) from Slough, fell out with Amar Hussain, who he had known since he was a young boy. Khan filled up a Coca Cola bottle with the acid and threw it in Mr Hussain's face.

item.title: Iranian OPEC governor dies aged 68 of a brain haemorrhage two weeks after falling into a coma
item.description: Veteran politician Hossein Kazempour-Ardebili died this morning. The 68-year-old had been in a coma in a hospital in Tehran, Iran, for two weeks after a brain haemorrhage.

item.title: The making of Prince Andrew
item.description: NIGEL CAWTHORNE: At his public appearances, girls screamed and even fainted - it was Beatlemania all over again, according to one commentator.

item.title: Boy, 15, is charged with attempted murder after man, 32, is stabbed in the street in Leeds
item.description: A 15-year-old has been charged with attempted murder after a man was stabbed in the street in Leeds while trying to stop thieves from stealing his son's bike at 9.18pm on May 14.

item.title: Terrifying moment kayakers freeze in fear after being circled by three killer whales
item.description: This is the terrifying moment three killer whales circled a pair of Russian kayakers who had paddled half a mile out to sea before one lurches towards them.

item.title: Has warm spring suppressed UK's outbreak? Coronavirus fell after sunniest April on record
item.description: Professor Keith Neal, an emeritus professor of epidemiology at the University of Nottingham, said vitamin D can also shield people from falling seriously unwell with COVID-19.

item.title: Chiropractor reveals all the common pains and injuries you get from sitting at a desk
item.description: A chiropractor has revealed the most common aches and pains you'll get from working at a desk all day and the simple stretches - and tools - to combat them.

item.title: Thieves who raided Dele Alli's house 'threatened to butcher girlfriend Ruby Mae's dog'
item.description: Robbers who broke into Dele Alli's £2million Hertfordshire mansion threatened to kill his girlfriend Ruby Mae's dog during the terrifying raid early on Wednesday morning.

item.title: Polish WWII fighter pilot, 97, dies of coronavirus in New York City
item.description: Jerzy Glowczewski, a Polish fighter pilot who fought with Britain during WWii, died of COVID-19 in New York City.

item.title: Remains of English sailor who became a samurai in Japan in 1600 formally identified
item.description: William Adams, the first Englishman ever to set foot in Japan , washed up in the country in 1600 on his way to the New World and became known as the 'blue-eyed samurai' after befriending a local warlord.

item.title: People in England will have to self-isolate for two weeks before going to hospital for routine ops
item.description: The rule will apply to all patients going for routine operations, even if they do not have any COVID-19 symptoms. It will affect roughly 700,000 patients a month in England.

item.title: Prince William pens a letter to thank the Fire and Rescue services amid coronavirus pandemic
item.description: Prince William, 37, has penned a letter to the National Fire Chiefs Council, praising the work of the Fire and Rescue Services amid the coronavirus pandemic.

item.title: Pictured: Married father charged after woman's dismembered body was found stuffed in two suitcases
item.description: Mahesh Sorathiya, from Wolverhampton was last night charged with assisting an offender after human remains were discovered in Gloucestershire on Tuesday evening.

item.title: Mother-of-four almost doubles the size of her house in a complete renovation
item.description: A family who wanted to get out of the rental market and purchase their own place have done so in unprecedented style, completely transforming a property in western Sydney.

item.title: NHS staff line streets at funeral for nurse, 54, his mother, 81 and father, 85
item.description: Keith Dunnington worked at the Queen Elizabeth Hospital in Gateshead, Tyne and Wear, as a staff nurse and spent 30 years on the front line. He died in April aged 54.

item.title: Sadiq Khan tells Londoners to stay home as map reveals new car free zones in the UK capital
item.description: Sadiq Khan has urged Londoners to stay at home this weekend as a detailed map reveals the four busy streets in the UK capital set to become car-free zones in a time frame of just six weeks.

item.title: Victoria Beckham gushes about spending time outdoors with daughter Harper and son Romeo
item.description: The fashion mogul, 46, shared a snap of daughter Harper, eight, and son Romeo, 17, in a field of flowers via Instagram on Saturday.

item.title: Fury as Unite blasts British Airways for 'betrayal' of thousands of workers
item.description: Senior British Airways cabin crew are facing a staggering 55 per cent pay cut with salaries slashed to £24,000. Airline bosses wrote to employees outlining the new salaries.

item.title: Schools chaos as second council REFUSES to restart classes next month but academies says they WILL
item.description: Children's Commissioner for England Anne Longfield warned that children were being harmed by the continued closure and they would have to return at some point before a cure for coronavirus was found.

item.title: Woman reveals fertility issues and cancerous cell discovery resulted in a full hysterectomy aged 30
item.description: Rachel Mason, 31, from Leigh-on-Sea, has spoken of her heartbreak after fertility issues and the discovery of cancerous cells resulted in her having a full hysterectomy at the age of 30.

item.title: Moment bungling burglar is found by police hiding in a bedroom cupboard in just his UNDERPANTS
item.description: This is the moment police find a burglar trying to hide in a bedroom cupboard wearing just his underpants after going on the run following a failed attempt to steal cigarettes from a shop.

item.title: Neil Ruddock downs pints at boozy party in photographs which sparked furious row with Paul Merson
item.description: Neil 'Razor' Ruddock downs pints and pours beers from pitchers in pictures from a boozy party that caused a row between the former England star and Paul Merson.

item.title: Important holy Jewish site in Iran is desecrated in 'premeditated' arson attack
item.description: The Tomb of Esther and Mordechai (pictured) is located in Hamadan, Iran is believed by some to house the remains of the biblical Queen Esther and her cousin Mordechai.

item.title: Gogglebox stars brutally SLAM Boris Johnson's lockdown speech for giving mixed messages
item.description: Googlebox stars left fans in hysterics after mocking Boris Johnson's lockdown speech which aired on May 10. Tom Snr did an impression of the Prime Minister to

item.title: Government awards £1billion in fast-tracked state contracts to firms WITHOUT public tender
item.description: The government has awarded state contracts worth over £1billion to deal with coronavirus to private firms without public tenders. The fast-track route means they didn't allow bids for the work.

item.title: Monty Python fan gets residents to perform versions of John Cleese sketch
item.description: James Ruffell, 37, put up sign outside his home in Sonning, Berkshire, which stated: 'You are now entering the jurisdiction of the Ministry of Silly Walks, commence silly walking immediately'.

item.title: Women across the country are hula-hooping
item.description: Five British hula hoop converts told FEMAIL they credit the classic playground activity with toning their tummies and shaping their waists - and admit they're 'addicted' to the effective exercise.

item.title: Russian bankers who lived life of luxury in UK having riches seized after racking up £730m debts
item.description: Financial investigators are searching to claim Mr Yurov (pictured) and Mr Fetisov's assets after they were accused of siphoning Russia's National Bank Trust savers' money to offshore companies.

item.title: Parents divided over June 1st school return
item.description: Parents across the UK are divided over sending their children back to education during the coronavirus crisis. FEMAIL have spoken to families who have revealed the reasons behind their choice.

item.title: Wall-to-wall sales for the rest of the year as shops gear up to reopen with stock up for grabs
item.description: An industry insider said warehouse storage space is more than 90 per cent full, meaning retailers have reportedly been storing summer fashion in railway sidings.

item.title: Ken Rees dies of cancer aged 76
item.description: Ken Rees was a familiar face on television throughout the 80s and 90s, reporting from across the world as he covered stories including the civil war in Beirut and Falklands campaign.

item.title: Record 25 women including Salma Hayek are now in the ten-figure fortune club
item.description: Twenty-five women billionaires are for the first time among the 1,000 richest people in Britain. And there are now 150 women who have, or share, personal fortunes worth £120million or more.

item.title: Wife reveals heartbreak after her husband, 30, died two days after the couple got married
item.description: Kirsty, 27, from Rochdale, has revealed her heartache after husband Gavin Howarth, 30, who received a shock cancer diagnosis on Easter Sunday, died two days after they tied the knot.

item.title: Is PHE facing the chop? Boris Johnson tells Tory MPs he plans post-pandemic review of 'institutions'
item.description: The Prime Minister informed a meeting of the 1922 Committee of backbench Conservatives that he was planning a review of 'a number of institutions' once coronavirus is beaten.

item.title: Captain Tom Moore says he's not scared of dying if he catches coronavirus
item.description: Captain Tom Moore dismissed any suggestion he was afraid of dying if he caught coronavirus and insisted he wanted to visit India again as well as drive Route 66 in America.

item.title: Academies WILL reopen primary schools by June 1 despite claims teachers and pupils will be at risk
item.description: Reach 2, Harris, Oasis and GEP, which teach a quarter of the UK's children have all thrown their weight behind controversial government proposals.

item.title: Touching moment nurse leaves hospital after overcoming coronavirus
item.description: Heartwarming footage revealed the moment Sue Snelson, from Scunthorpe, who is in her sixties, was applauded as she left the intensive care unit she used to manage after overcoming coronavirus.

item.title: No Time To Die becomes the most expensive James Bond film EVER with £200 million cost
item.description: No Time To Die has become the most expensive James Bond film ever made, with Daniel Craig's final outing as 007 costing a whopping £200 million to make.

item.title: Bill Turnbull, 64, candidly discusses why he is 'very calm' about the prospect of dying
item.description: The journalist, 64, has given an update on living with prostate cancer three years after being diagnosed with the incurable illness.

item.title: The Duchess of Cambridge has rewritten the royal history books
item.description: Jenny Johnston spoke to professional photographers for their opinion on recent snaps taken by the Duchess of Cambridge. The royal is urging everyone to upload images from lockdown.

item.title: CDC director says models predict coronavirus deaths will accelerate in coming weeks
item.description: 'CDC tracks 12 different forecasting models of possible COVID-19 deaths in the US,' Dr. Robert R. Redfield said in a tweet. 'As of May 11, all forecast an increase in deaths in the coming weeks.'

item.title: Dutch government advises singletons looking for intimacy to come to agreement with regular partner
item.description: The National Institute for Public Health and the Environment (RIVM) said that single people should come to an agreement with one other person if they are seeking intimacy.

item.title: Tennis coach Judy Murray recalls her travel adventures
item.description: Judy Murray, mother of Scottish tennis stars Andy and Jamie, talks about early holidays with her sons, reveals that the Isle of Harris is the most unusual place she's ever played tennis - and more...

item.title: Part two of our tribute to Florence Nightingale through fascinating objects
item.description: This month is the 200th anniversary since British nurse Florence Nightingale was born. Andrew Preston tells her story using a selection of fascinating objects in a tribute.

item.title: NHS boss reveals patient numbers for Covid-19 have dropped by 10,000 in just a few weeks
item.description: EXCLUSIVE: NHS Chief Executive Simon Stevens says that while we are 'not yet out of the woods' but that hard work and the public's own actions have ensured the NHS has not been overwhelmed.

item.title: UK campsites are all set to welcome guests and these ones are pitch perfect from Devon to Wales
item.description: From pitches tucked away in the trees to sites overlooking the ocean, we've tracked down the best UK campsites with stringent measures in place, so you can get back to nature this summer.

item.title: Britain the cocaine capital of Europe as usage soars by almost 300 per cent
item.description: Estimates on the amount of the Class A substance being trafficked into the country has risen three-fold since 2011 to 117 tonnes, Lawrence Gibbons of the National Crime Agency told the Times.

item.title: John Stapleton reveals grief in first interview since the death of his wife Lynn
item.description: Campaigner, consumer champion and TV presenter Lynn Faulds Wood, who has died of a stroke, seemed for years to be invincible. Her husband John Stapleton speaks of his grief.

item.title: New Zealand Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern is REJECTED from a cafe under COVID-19 restrictions
item.description: Ms Ardern and her partner Clarke Gayford attempted to dine at Olive, in Wellington, on Saturday morning.

item.title: David Niven's lessons in love from a teacher wearing nothing but stockings
item.description: DAVID NIVEN: Left to my own devices, I began walking round Picadilly in the evenings, admiring the neon signs, and was soon exploring Mayfair and Soho.

item.title: Buyers could be subjected to 'health screenings' from estate agents over the phone for Covid-19
item.description: On 13 May, over 5million people visited Rightmove in 24 hours, marking a 4 per cent increase on a year ago, the online site said.

item.title: Elderly with coronavirus were knowingly sent away from hospitals the devastated by fatal outbreaks
item.description: Government guidelines until April 16 said coronavirus patients could be released into care homes. A dozen residents died at St Nicholas Care Home in Bootle, Liverpool, after two patients to it.

item.title: Trump fires State Department inspector general
item.description: The president on Friday fired Steve Linick, an Obama administration appointee whose office had been critical of alleged political bias in the State Department's management.

item.title: Heart stopping moment Air Force Thunderbird takes evasive action as delta formation breaks apart
item.description: The U.S. Air Force Thunderbirds were conducting a flypast of LA and San Diego on Friday but suddenly one of the aircraft was forced to take evasive action and left the formation.

item.title: MELANIE BLAKE lays bare the demands from A-listers' sex lives to drugs passed around like sweets
item.description: MELANIE BLAKE: The moment I was standing at a party at London's Claridge's hotel was when I truly realised my life had come a long way from a Saturday job in a record store in Stockport.

item.title: German photographer who shot some of the earlier images of the Beatles dies aged 81
item.description: Astrid Kirchherr (left with John Lennon) died on Tuesday in her native Hamburg, days before her 82nd birthday, her friend Kai-Uwe Franz said.

item.title: PAUL THOMAS on... Parents waiting for their children to go back to school after lockdown
item.description: PAUL THOMAS on... Parents waiting for their children to go back to school after lockdown: 'The thought of me not going back to school on June 1st tipped her over the edge'

item.title: Eighty gestures are decoded as scientists discover that chimpanzees have a secret language
item.description: EXCLUSIVE They are man's closest relatives but until now it has mainly been a mystery how they communicate. Now scientists believe they may have cracked the secret language of chimpanzees.

item.title: The 27 cars new on sale with terrible all-round visibility
item.description: A combination of safety requirements and styling have resulted in the windows of cars shrinking and the door pillars becoming chunkier - a recipe that doesn't bode well for driving visibility.

item.title: How an Indian billionaire ended up in a Wandsworth jail cell fighting claims of a gigantic fraud
item.description: His handlebar moustache 'disguise' has long gone. So, too, the £10,000 ostrich-hide jacket he was sporting when his whereabouts as a 'fugitive' in England were first uncovered.

item.title: New York's 420,000 wealthiest residents fled the city in two months, new smartphone data shows
item.description: Five percent of New York City's population, or 420,000 people, left between March 1 and May 1 amid the coronavirus pandemic. Residents were typically white and earned more than $100,000.

item.title: BEL MOONEY: Am I selfish for dating a much younger woman?
item.description: This week Bel Mooney advises a 58-year-old man who is dating a woman half his age on whether to end their relationship to give her a chance to have a life.

item.title: A little Italy... in Greece: The undiscovered island of Syros is an Italianate masterpiece
item.description: Syros is an island of 22,000 souls in the Greek Cyclades that boasts a beautiful capital, Ermoupoli. John Malathronas visited and found a city that looks more Italian than Greek.

item.title: Travel insurance for summer travel could be tricky - here's how Saga and Aviva are reacting
item.description: The mention of 'travel bubbles' across Europe keeps hopes of a sunshine break alive. But there's a big sticking point - travel insurance. So how are the main providers reacting to this?

item.title: Women are showing off foraged meals, frolicking in fields and donning gingham dresses
item.description: As city life grinds to a halt, nostalgic millennials in Britain and further afield are going back to basics, plumping for a romaticised version of life away from the big smoke, perhaps as a form of escapism.
